text: And for obvious reasons, perhaps, I've been reminded in recent days, recent months, of the brevity of life. And you say, Pastor, you're young. I do feel like I'm still young. But the reality is that just recently I celebrated my 42nd birthday. And you say, I wish I were 42. I understand. But here's what the psalmist says, that we spend our years as a tale that is told. The days of our years are three score years and ten. And so if I have 70 or 80 years, I've already expended half of those. And some of you said, I'm living on borrowed time. Amen. And the reality, though, is when you see your daughter married, it makes you all of a sudden think, man, life is going fast. And I can remember bringing Juliana home from the hospital. And I can remember walking through our house at the time and showing her all of the rooms and acting like she could understand what I was telling her and telling her where her bedroom would be and so on and so forth. And then I remember the first evening, and Josh and Aaron, not to discourage you, but I remember the first evening at home, she didn't sleep a wink. And it was just cry, cry, cry. And she had slept good at the hospital. And Holly was just not getting any sleep whatsoever. And there was a good husband. I said, I got it. Blake, amen, right? I said, I got it. I can handle this. And I took Juliana out in the living room. And I bet you, I mean, I don't think it was five minutes. Five minutes is dad time for sure. And I went back into the room and Holly sat straight up in the bed and she said, what's wrong? And I said, I don't know. I think she needs to go back to the hospital. And that was my medical training kicking into high gear. And there's no other option here. She must go back to the hospital. And obviously Holly was able to handle things. But the reality is that all of a sudden you start thinking about life and the brevity of life. And life is short. James tells us, what is your life? As we're going to think about the just life in general, and I begin to think about the New Testament and obviously having Acts 20, we're going to look at a number of passages this morning. But I think about our life as God would use in the New Testament, really as an analogy of our life, that of a race. It's likened to a race. We think about this analogy that God would use, and we'd often say over the years that this race is more like a marathon than it is a sprint. But you think about a race and there's a finish line. And for us, we understand that's when we will take our last breath upon this earth and see our Savior, and what a wonderful joy that will be. But the reality is that we don't know where the finish line is. We understand, as I've read there from Psalm 90, the 70 or 80 years. And yet we find that if we were to visit a cemetery, a graveyard today, that you will find as you walk through those rows of headstones, you will find a variety of ages of those that have deceased. And we find that though I may think at 42 years old that I have many years until I reach my finish line, the fact of the matter is that my finish line could be before yours. And the Bible tells us that Paul says, but none of these things move me, neither count I my life dear unto myself, so that I might finish my course with joy. And the ministry which I have received of the Lord Jesus to testify the gospel of the grace of God. And I read that statement here in Acts 20 and verse number 24, and many of us are familiar with 2 Timothy chapter number 4, turn over there if you will, in 2 Timothy chapter number 4, and I want you to notice that Paul now is writing to his son in the faith, and of course if we could have the picture of a race and really this marathon, we find that Paul is seeking to instruct Timothy and to give Timothy, really kind of pass that baton, if you will, to Timothy. And as a child of God, when we consider this stated purpose this morning, it's good for us to have a stated purpose. It's important that we would have such a purpose. It's imperative, however, that we would have a plan that would help us get to that desired end. He comes to the end of his life and he says, I finished. I've kept the faith. How did he get there? How did he get there? As we begin to develop a strategic plan for our own lives, we remember and we're mindful of the fact that we have an enemy who wants to devour us. We have an enemy that wants to destroy us. I have five thoughts for you on how we could develop a strategic plan. This is not an exhaustive plan, just five thoughts, but I think first and foremost we must develop a proper view of God. You say, well, the finish line is far away. If you think that way, it's unlikely that you will finish with no regrets because the reality is that the finish line may be closer than you think it is. It may be closer than you think it is. With God's help and by God's grace, we can have that same testimony that Paul has and we can have that spectacular proclamation that I finished. I did what God called me to do. I kept the faith and I'm going to receive a crown. Again, not pridefully speaking, just understanding what God has said in His Word. Finish with no regrets, let us pray. Father, how we love You. How we thank You for loving us. We thank You for Your precious Word. God, I pray this morning that You've used Your Word to help someone. The reality this morning is that none of us know exactly where we are in our race, how many days we actually have left upon this earth. Not only is our life a vapor, but Your return is imminent. God, I pray that You'd help us this morning to have this same. stated purpose of Paul. God, would you help us to develop a strategic plan in our lives that we may be able to make the same type of declaration, this spectacular proclamation of Paul. Help us, Lord. There's one that's present that's not sure of heaven. They've never trusted the Lord Jesus Christ as their personal Savior. God, I pray that today the Holy Spirit of God would convict them of their sin of Christ's righteousness and of judgment to come. I pray that before they would leave this place that they would get their salvation settled. I pray for every child of God. Would you help us, Lord, to develop this proper view, to have this strategic plan that we might finish with no regrets. As we have a few moments of invitation, I pray, God, that you'd move and work as only you can. Help us to take this time to do business with you, that we would truly allow you to have your way in our lives, that we'd leave here different than we arrived, that we'd be doers of the Word and not hearers only. We'll give you the glory for what you'll do, for it's in Christ's name we pray. Would you stand with us?

segments.text: And for obvious reasons, perhaps, I've been reminded in recent days, recent months, of the brevity of life.
And you say, Pastor, you're young. I do feel like I'm still young.
But the reality is that just recently I celebrated my 42nd birthday.
And you say, I wish I were 42. I understand.
But here's what the psalmist says, that we spend our years as a tale that is told.
The days of our years are three score years and ten.
And so if I have 70 or 80 years, I've already expended half of those.
And some of you said, I'm living on borrowed time. Amen.
And the reality, though, is when you see your daughter married,
it makes you all of a sudden think, man, life is going fast.
And I can remember bringing Juliana home from the hospital.
And I can remember walking through our house at the time and showing her all of the rooms
and acting like she could understand what I was telling her
and telling her where her bedroom would be and so on and so forth.
And then I remember the first evening, and Josh and Aaron, not to discourage you,
but I remember the first evening at home, she didn't sleep a wink.
And it was just cry, cry, cry. And she had slept good at the hospital.
And Holly was just not getting any sleep whatsoever.
And there was a good husband. I said, I got it.
Blake, amen, right? I said, I got it. I can handle this.
And I took Juliana out in the living room. And I bet you, I mean, I don't think it was five minutes.
Five minutes is dad time for sure.
And I went back into the room and Holly sat straight up in the bed and she said, what's wrong?
And I said, I don't know. I think she needs to go back to the hospital.
And that was my medical training kicking into high gear.
And there's no other option here. She must go back to the hospital.
And obviously Holly was able to handle things.
But the reality is that all of a sudden you start thinking about life and the brevity of life.
And life is short. James tells us, what is your life?
It's a vapor that appears for a little time and then vanisheth away.
As we're going to think about the just life in general,
and I begin to think about the New Testament and obviously having Acts 20,
we're going to look at a number of passages this morning.
But I think about our life as God would use in the New Testament,
really as an analogy of our life, that of a race. It's likened to a race.
We think about this analogy that God would use,
and we'd often say over the years that this race is more like a marathon than it is a sprint.
But you think about a race and there's a finish line.
And for us, we understand that's when we will take our last breath upon this earth
and see our Savior, and what a wonderful joy that will be.
But the reality is that we don't know where the finish line is.
We understand, as I've read there from Psalm 90, the 70 or 80 years.
And yet we find that if we were to visit a cemetery, a graveyard today,
that you will find as you walk through those rows of headstones,
you will find a variety of ages of those that have deceased.
And we find that though I may think at 42 years old that I have many years until I reach my finish line,
the fact of the matter is that my finish line could be before yours.
I sat in the room of a lady that was dying with cancer several years ago,
and the doctors had told her it would just be a couple of days before she would leave this earth,
and her husband was lost.
And I sat in that room with the husband and the wife and another family member,
and she had a testimony of salvation, the lady with cancer, but the husband was lost.
And I looked at that man and I said,
you understand that the doctors have said that within just a few days your wife is going to pass from this earth,
but the reality, sir, is that you could possibly die before her.
I don't have anything wrong.
You know how many people go on the highway every day?
I don't think they have anything wrong.
And bam, they're in eternity.
So we think about this truth of our lives, and we think about seeking to reach that finish line,
and really some have said it this way,
finishing is more important, or how you finish is more important than how you start.
I never ran in track. It was never my, I don't have the build for track, obviously.
I played baseball and football, but I understood some things about track and field,
and one of the things, you're going to run a race,
you know, the guy that starts out 100 miles an hour to start,
he may run out of steam pretty quick.
And we look at the Christian life, and as I consider the remarks of Paul here in Acts chapter number 20,
as he's speaking to the leaders of the church at Ephesus,
and he's called them together to where he is as he's on his way to Jerusalem,
and he's going to give them some parting statements, he's going to seek to encourage them,
but Paul makes a statement in Acts 20 and verse 24 that really just grabs my attention.
And the Bible tells us that Paul says,
but none of these things move me, neither count I my life dear unto myself,
so that I might finish my course with joy.
And the ministry which I have received of the Lord Jesus
to testify the gospel of the grace of God.
As Paul is speaking to these leaders of the church at Ephesus,
he is going to tell them of his own desire that he wants to finish his course with joy.
And I read that statement here in Acts 20 and verse number 24,
and many of us are familiar with 2 Timothy chapter number 4,
turn over there if you will, in 2 Timothy chapter number 4,
and I want you to notice that Paul now is writing to his son in the faith,
and of course if we could have the picture of a race and really this marathon,
we find that Paul is seeking to instruct Timothy and to give Timothy,
really kind of pass that baton, if you will, to Timothy.
In fact, in the second chapter of the book of 2 Timothy,
he says, the things that thou hast heard of me among many witnesses,
the same commit thou to faithful men who shall be able to teach others also.
Though Paul's race was nearing the end, his life here on earth was nearing the end,
he was seeking to invest and influence Timothy,
who would still continue to run his leg of the race, if you will,
that he would have that responsibility.
But we come to the fourth chapter, and Paul says this in verse number 6,
under the inspiration of the Holy Spirit of God,
for I am now ready to be offered.
The time of my departure is at hand.
Notice when he says, I have fought a good fight,
I have finished my course,
I have kept the faith.
As I look at the statement in verse number 7,
he says, I have finished my course,
and then he says, I have kept the faith.
I really believe that those two statements are really dependent upon one another,
and they really reveal to us what we find in Acts 20 and verse number 24,
when he says that I might finish my course with joy.
The keeping the faith was the joyful part of finishing his course.
And we find here this morning that as we look at the statement of Paul in Acts 20 and verse number 24,
and we read 2 Timothy 4 and verses 6 and 7,
the big question in my mind is,
how do we get from Acts 20 and 24 to 2 Timothy 4, 6 and 7?
How do we get from, I want to finish my course with joy,
to, I have finished.
I've kept the faith.
How do we get there?
Let me say this, right at the beginning, it's not going to happen by chance.
It's not going to happen on accident.
And I've titled the message, Finish with No Regrets.
Finish with No Regrets.
I want you to think about this if you're taking notes this morning from Acts 20 and verse number 24.
I would say this, there is a stated purpose.
A stated purpose.

neither count I my life dear unto myself.

that I might finish my course with joy.

that we would have as our purpose statement,
that we seek to bring honor and glory to God,

that we would do all that God has called us to do.

but I really get the idea of finishing strong.
says in verse 24, that I might finish my course with joy and the ministry which I

He understood that he'd been given a ministry, been given a responsibility, and
Paul says I want to finish. And I don't want to just finish, I want to finish

race. They want to kick it in for that last period of time. They want to finish

No, I want to be poured out. I want to leave it all. I want to finish strong. Not

and in the power of His might. That in the evil day that we could stand, not in

Paul says I want to finish my course. I want to finish with joy. I want to finish
with strength. I have this idea that I'd like to finish pleasing the one for whom
I live. You think about those that run a race. Physically speaking, many times
there are spectators. There are people that are applauding as they get to the

medal category. But I want to finish my race. I want to finish my life pleasing
the one who died for me. The one for whom we live. And we find that Paul is
recognizing that the Lord Jesus Christ saved him, gave him a ministry, and I
believe that he took the responsibility seriously. He clearly indicates and he
wants others to know what his desire is. He's not keeping this private. He's
saying publicly to these leaders of the church at Ephesus, he says, listen, I want
to finish my course with joy. I want to do what God's called me to do. A stated
purpose. A stated purpose is important. Any successful corporation or any
corporation who desires to be successful is going to have a mission statement.
When they have that mission statement, it clearly sets what the goal, the objective
is. What is their purpose? Why are they in business? What are they seeking to
accomplish? And as a child of God, when we consider this stated purpose this
morning, it's good for us to have a stated purpose. It'd be good for everyone
to leave here and say, I want to finish my course with joy. But the truth of the
matter is that a stated purpose requires, number two, a strategic plan because it
will not happen by chance. It will not happen on accident that we finish with
joy, that we finish with no regrets. We think about the purpose that we
would stay as Paul did in Acts 20 and verse 24. It's important that we would
have such a purpose. It's imperative, however, that we would have a plan that
would help us get to that desired end. That's why we read Acts 20 and then read
2 Timothy chapter number 4 because we find that it's in Acts 20 that Paul
makes this declaration, but we find that it's in 2 Timothy 4. He comes to the
end of his life and he says, I finished. I've kept the faith. How did he get there?
How did he get there? As we begin to develop a strategic plan for our own lives, we
remember and we're mindful of the fact that we have an enemy who wants to
devour us. We have an enemy that wants to destroy us. We have an enemy that wants
to hinder us from doing what God's called us to do. In fact, Paul says it
this way to the believers in Galatia. Those were the churches that were
established during that first missionary journey. What a joy to see how the
church at Antioch sent out Paul and Barnabas and they went. And you think
about those four churches that were established in those cities, but Paul
says, ye did run well. Who did hinder you that you should not obey the truth? In
Galatians 5 and verse number 7. See, there's an enemy and the enemy wants to
hinder us. The enemy wants to keep us from trying to reach that stated purpose,
that goal, and we find it as we have the opportunity to develop a strategic plan
that God would help us to reach that stated purpose, to accomplish the
goal that we've stated. I have five thoughts for you on how we could develop
a strategic plan. This is not an exhaustive plan, just five thoughts, but I
think first and foremost we must develop a proper view of God. If we don't see God
in his rightful place, everything else is going to kind of fall apart. I think
about Isaiah in Isaiah chapter number 6. In the year that King Uzziah died, Isaiah saw
the Lord high and lifted up. His train did fill the temple. Heard the angels say,
holy, holy, holy. Our God is holy. And as we see our God in his rightful place, as
we understand and we develop that proper view of who God is, it really sets
everything else in order. And if we do not have that established up front, if we
do not develop that proper view of God, it's going to be very challenging for us
to have a proper view of anything else in life. We must understand and
acknowledge that he is King of Kings, and he is Lord of Lords, that he is the Lord
God omnipotent, and he reigns, he rules. And we find that he's our Savior, he's
our Redeemer, he is our Lord. We develop that proper view of God, we see him high,
holy, and lifted up, and we find that, listen, the only way this morning for you
to develop a proper view of God is going to be by getting into this book.
You understand this morning that Congress isn't going to give you a
proper view of who God is. You understand this morning that the
entertainment business is not going to give you a proper view of who God is. You
understand this morning that the school house is not going to give you a

God be true and every man a liar. We find this morning that we must dig into the

that only see the heavens and they don't have this book, they
understand that somebody had to do this, but they don't know who that somebody is.
They can't know him intimately if they do not have the Word of God. And so we
develop that proper view of who God is. After developing a proper view of who
God is, number two, we would develop a proper view of self. I will never have a

for that."
